Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Botulinum Toxin Type A in Tibial Distraction Osteogenesis

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the leg level

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients undergoing stature lengthening with either lengthening over a nail or lengthening and then nailing.

Intervention.evidence: Each patient received a 200 IU BtX-A injection in one calf muscle, while the contralateral leg received a saline injection as a control.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of Botulinum Toxin Type A (BtX-A) in reducing calf pain and improving range of motion (ROM) during tibial distraction osteogenesis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the difference in calf pain measured by VAS scores and ROM of the knees and ankles, assessed until the end of the consolidation phase.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the leg level, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: In this double-blind, randomised controlled trial

Number_Randomised.evidence: 36 patients undergoing bilateral tibia lengthening were enrolled between April 2010 and January 2011.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were observed in calf pain, knee and ankle ROM, or maximal calf circumferences between the treated and control legs at any time point.
